treatments.name: Fungicides
treatments.description: Apply a fungicide containing captan or myclobutanil according to the label instructions. Repeat applications may be necessary, especially during wet periods.

treatments.name: Sanitation
treatments.description: Remove and destroy fallen leaves in the autumn to reduce the source of infection for the following year. This is a critical step in long-term control.

general_advice.advice: Maintain good air circulation around trees by pruning and spacing. This helps leaves dry quickly, reducing the risk of fungal diseases.
Prune infected branches during dormancy to remove sources of the disease. Dispose of pruned material properly.

treatments.name: Fungicides
treatments.description: Apply a fungicide labeled for black rot, such as those containing copper, mancozeb, or propiconazole, following label instructions. Applications are often most effective when made preventatively, before symptoms appear.

treatments.name: Sanitation
treatments.description: Remove and destroy mummified fruit, fallen leaves, and pruned branches to eliminate sources of the fungus. This is essential for controlling black rot.

general_advice.advice: Remove mummified fruit from the tree and ground promptly. This prevents the fungus from overwintering and infecting new fruit the following year.
Prune out cankered branches, cutting several inches below the affected area. Dispose of the pruned material properly.
Improve air circulation around the tree by pruning and spacing. This helps to dry the leaves and fruit, reducing the risk of fungal infection.

treatments.name: Fungicides
treatments.description: Apply a fungicide containing myclobutanil, fenbuconazole, or propiconazole, following label instructions. Apply at bud break and repeat as needed, especially during wet springs.

treatments.name: Removal of Cedar Trees (if practical)
treatments.description: If feasible, removing nearby cedar trees (the alternate host) can help break the disease cycle. This is often a long-term solution but may not always be practical.

general_advice.advice: Rake up and dispose of fallen apple leaves in the autumn to reduce the overwintering inoculum.
Prune out galls on cedar trees during the dormant season to reduce the source of spores. This is best done in late winter or early spring.
Space apple trees appropriately to improve air circulation and reduce humidity, which can favor fungal growth.
Regularly inspect your apple trees for signs of disease or pests. Early detection is key to effective treatment.
Provide proper care, including adequate watering, fertilization, and pruning, to keep your trees healthy and resistant to disease.
Practice good sanitation by removing fallen leaves and debris around the trees. This helps prevent the buildup of disease-causing organisms.
